(44) 721.llth December, 1944.WAR CABINET.THE MINISTER RESIDENT IN WEST AFRICA.Directive by the Prime Minister.*YOU have been appointed Cabinet Minister Resident in West Africa, and your headquarters will be at Achimota in the Gold Coast. Your sphere will include the territories of Nigeria, the Gold Coast, Sierra Leone, and the Gambia,and also Liberia and Fernando Po. Your appointment will not in any wayimpair the existing responsibilities of the Governors or Commanders-in-Chief inthe British territories, or their special relationships with their respective Depart-ments at home, with whom they will continue to correspond direct.2. You will serve under, and report direct to, the War Cabinet, through itsSecretary. The main purpose of your appointment will be to ensure the effective co-operation, for all purposes connected with the prosecution of the war, of all services, Civil and Military, in West Africa. For this purpose you will fromtime to time summon meetings of the West African War Council, and of its CivilMembers' and Service Members' Committees, and will preside over such meetings.3. It will be your special duty to see that the resources and needs of theBritish territories within your sphere are, so far as possible, dealt with as a whole,in order to ensure the most effective use of those resources for the war effort.4. Your functions will also include the prompt settlement of matters withinthe policy of His Majesty's Government, more particularly where severalauthorities or Departments are concerned.5. In the political sphere you will give broad political guidance to theOommanders-in-Chief. You will also take steps to maintain the best possiblerelations with the French and Belgian authorities in West Africa. His Majesty'sConsuls-General at Dakar, Brazzaville and Leopoldville and His Majesty'sConsul at Duala will be instructed to send you copies of their reports. You will,* This Directive replaces that issued to Lord Swinton (W.P. (42) 245).[28797] however, bear in mind that both the Belgian Government and the French Pro-visional Government are extremely sensitive about any suggestion of Britishtutelage over their African territories and that they have insisted (and we haveagreed) that all questions of policy, military, political or economic, shall be dealtwith in Europe, and that they leave very little latitude in these matters to their local colonial authorities. Similarly, you will take steps to ensure the promptsettlement of problems arising out of the ever-increasing interests of the UnitedStates in your sphere.6. In dealing with any questions concerning Fernando Po, you should,whenever possible, consult the home authorities in advance in order that consideration may be given to the possible bearing of any action upon Anglo-Spanish relations.7. You will be fully informed of the approved policy of His Majesty'sGovernment on all major issues affecting your responsibilities. If any question arises on which you require special guidance you will, provided that there is time,refer the matter home. You will, in any case, report from time to time to HisMajesty's Government and will receive their directions.8. Your normal channel of communication will be through the Secretaryof State for the Colonies. On Departmental matters your telegrams will, when necessary, be addressed to the Ministers concerned through that channel. Youwill also address personal telegrams to the Prime Minister and Minister ofDefence on defence matters. In general, except where an immediate decision isrequired, you will consult the home authorities on any proposed action before itis taken if it is not clearly in accordance with approved or accepted policy.When, on grounds of urgency, you act on any important matter without prior-consultation with London, you will report the circumstances as soon as possible.W. S. O.10 Downing Street, S.W. 1,11th December, 1944.
